skill.name: reviewing-code
skill.description: Provides structured code review guidance with quality checklists and validation commands for pull requests and code changes.
skill.summary: Structured code review guidance with quality checklists and validation commands
skill.author: BPSAI

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill contains only documentation and example commands for code review workflows. All detected patterns are legitimate bash commands and git examples for validating code quality. No actual executable code, network access, or security risks identified.

content.user_title: Review Code Changes with Structured Quality Checklists
content.value_statement: Code reviews can be inconsistent and miss critical issues without a clear framework. This skill provides structured review templates and validation commands to ensure thorough, consistent code quality assessment across pull requests.
actual_capabilities: Provides structured review output format with must-fix, should-fix, and consider sections
Offers quick validation commands for running tests, linting, and structure checks
Includes project-specific quality checklists for type hints, docstrings, and testing
Supplies git commands for analyzing code changes and finding common issues
Guides review verdicts with approve, approve-with-comments, or request-changes options
limitations: Requires bpsai-pair tool to be installed for ci and validate commands
Project-specific checks assume Python development conventions
Does not automatically run checks, only provides guidance and commands

use_cases.title: Pull Request Review
use_cases.description: Review incoming pull requests with structured checklist to identify bugs, style issues, and missing tests before merging code changes.

use_cases.title: Pre-Commit Quality Check
use_cases.description: Validate your own code changes before creating a pull request to ensure all quality standards are met and common issues are resolved.

use_cases.title: Code Quality Audit
use_cases.description: Perform systematic quality assessment of existing codebase sections to identify technical debt, missing documentation, and improvement opportunities.

prompt_templates.title: Review My Changes
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the changes in my current branch against main using the code review checklist
prompt_templates.scenario: You have uncommitted changes and want a quick quality check before committing

prompt_templates.title: Analyze Pull Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Review pull request #123 and provide structured feedback using the review format
prompt_templates.scenario: You need to review a team member's pull request with consistent criteria

prompt_templates.title: Find Common Issues
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the quick checks to find debug statements, TODOs, and potential secrets in my changes
prompt_templates.scenario: You want to catch common mistakes before pushing code

prompt_templates.title: Full Quality Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Run all validation checks including tests, linting, and structure validation for my branch
prompt_templates.scenario: You need comprehensive quality assurance before merging to production

output_examples.input: Review the changes in my current branch
output_examples.output: Running git diff analysis and applying code review checklist. Found 3 must-fix issues: missing type hints on new functions (auth.py:42), hardcoded API endpoint (config.py:15), and no tests for new feature (test coverage gap). 2 should-fix suggestions for docstring improvements. Overall recommendation: Request changes to address type safety and testing before approval.

output_examples.input: Check my code for common issues before committing
output_examples.output: Running quick checks on staged changes. Found 2 debug print statements in utils.py:28 and app.py:105 that should be removed. Detected 1 TODO comment in service.py:67 that needs resolution. No secrets or credentials detected. Recommend removing debug code before committing.

best_practices: Run the full CI validation suite before requesting reviews to catch obvious issues early
Use the structured review format consistently to ensure all code changes receive the same level of scrutiny
Always check for debug statements and TODOs in changes before approving pull requests
anti_patterns: Skipping the project-specific checks section when reviewing critical production code
Approving changes without running the validation commands to verify tests and linting pass
Using only automated checks without manual review of logic and design decisions

faq.question: What is the bpsai-pair tool required for some commands?
faq.answer: The bpsai-pair tool is a development workflow helper that runs integrated CI checks and project validation. The skill works without it by using individual git and validation commands instead.

faq.question: Can this skill automatically approve or reject pull requests?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance and review structure only. A human reviewer must make the final approval decision based on the analysis and checklist results.

faq.question: Does this work with languages other than Python?
faq.answer: The core review structure and git commands work with any language. However, the project-specific checks assume Python conventions like type hints and docstrings.

faq.question: How do I customize the review checklist for my project?
faq.answer: The skill provides a template format. You can modify the project-specific checks section in the skill file to match your team standards and coding conventions.

faq.question: Will this catch all security vulnerabilities in code?
faq.answer: No, this skill focuses on code quality and common issues. It includes basic checks for hardcoded secrets but is not a comprehensive security scanning tool.

faq.question: Can I use this for reviewing my own code before committing?
faq.answer: Yes, the validation commands and quick checks are designed for self-review workflows to catch issues before creating pull requests or pushing changes.
